I agree with Konester. There should be an additional argument to the op command to allow setting an operator's op level when adding them as an operator.
"/op <string, player name> [integer, operator level]"

It is not convenient to stop the entire server just to give one player access to the gamemode command for example, since you have to stop the server, and then start it up again for the modified operator config file to take effect. This is especially troublesome when your server is active with multiple users logged in as this disrupts gameplay for all players.
I agree, would be helpfull!

Something like this would solve entities that are summoned with the invisibility effect appearing for a moment before becoming invisible. It would also allow entities that cannot become invisible fully or at all, (like examples OP posted, or the Vex, who becomes translucent instead, minecarts, boats, etc.) to be invisible. I have noticed that even if you texture some parts of mobs to be invisible, like a shulker's head, they can still glitch while inside of blocks and have a pure black texture. I think this feature would be amazing for both custom map making and data packs.
This would be incredibly nice to use in commands!
I am in a situation where I need a minecart invisible, and I don't want to retexture it. Please add Mojang!

As of 1.16.100, the selector and score components have been added, meaning you can now display selectors and scores:

tellraw @a {"rawtext":[{"selector":"@p"},{"text":" is the closest player and has a score of "},{"score":{"name":"@p","objective":"score"}}]}

Hi there, This feedback is incomplete and not really useable by our team in its current form. Can you explain what you're looking for? Thanks, it will help us express your idea to the team in an actionable way.

Maybe to command a rainbow you have to make it rain first? The command could be something like /rainbowstart ?
Well, first we need rainbows in Minecraft, then a command...
Perhaps make it so a certain task is faster with a rainbow like with raining and fishing, perhaps an increased change of a magical mob spawning.
What do you mean command??? It should just happen naturally...

/gamerule RainbowAfterRain TRUE/FALSE
/rainbow ~ ~ ~

/back never existed in vanilla, it was from a server plugin. One command that could kind of substitute for what you are talking about is /spawnpoint, which would set your spawn point to your current location so that when you die you respawn at that location. You can also do /spawnpoint <player> to set a certain player's spawnpoint to your current location, or you can do /spawnpoint <player> <x> <y> <z> to set a certain player's spawnpoint to the location at x, y, and z. For example, /spawnpoint @s 0 64 0 would set your own spawnpoint to 0, 64, 0.
@Andre Chen, I did not know that. Thanks for the info!
Ps no se q dicir xd
Yes, we need an official randomizer.
It would make more sense to have it be 1?5 instead of 1..5 in order to avoid confusion. Also, why just stop there with scoreboard commands when that can be implemented with other commands?

This is already a feature on Bedrock, meaning it will most likely be added to Java edition anyway sometime in the future. Besides that, Java already has tons of ways to do randomization, including the new option through predicates (the days of using loot tables and various items are already gone). So it's honestly not even necessary and won't be much of an issue if it doesn't come to Java.
I would find it more usefull if the range could be choosen using other scoreboard players!

@ Mince Rafter 1, Well the point of them adding that would be to make things a lot more intuitive. Not adding that because we can technically already do randomization through more difficult means is like saying Mojang shouldn't add functions into Minecraft all because we can already make stuff with command blocks. It's just best if they scrap scoreboard random and replace it with the scoreboard ranges that this person is proposing. Remember command stats? Guess what? The original way of doing command stats was replaced with a better method in 1.13+. So replacing scoreboard random with ranges would be an excellent and far better idea.

Yes, Bedrock Parity in this regard would be really nice. The current ways of doing it are not very straight forward.

And I guess allowing for a "?" syntax or something similar in other commands like give etc would be really nice, but having a random number generator in the first place would already be a good step.

@Luggibumm: You can still do that using a little bit of math afterwards, so just allowing us to use fixed values is good enough.
It would be awesome to have a random number generator built into the game! Lots of uses!
Great idea

The only question I have is how do players add a seed to the random function? Could the 1?5 syntax add a set of parenthesis with a generators name, the seed being set with another function (i.e. /random set some_generator 12345) so the syntax could be 1?5(some_generator)

I think you should specify the player that it is and what they are holding and wearing. This could go hand in hand with: NBT-Ideas-Texture-and-Friendliness.

Make it fake_player or npc. The player entity is special because it's partially controlled by the client, it doesn't have an id tag, it always has the same UUID because it's linked to a Minecraft account, and a bunch of other things.
I feel like you should ba able to tell them what they should do, so that you do not have to work through all of the commands while making maps

I always used carpet mod for this feature and I think this would make a great addition to the vanilla game.
They may do this though the random tick speed gamerule. They also may add a way to prevent the copper from converting without commands (bit like water keeping the colour in correl blocks)
Perhaps you could use a brush to polish tarnished copper too.
Another way to do it would just be to have polished copper or somethin that doesn't rust.

I think this would be better as a numerical game rule like random tick speed, but as a different game rule from random tick speed itself. Some people like to play on worlds or servers for a very long time, so a way to have the rusting take place over a long time (for example, a month of real time), without messing up the rates of crop growth and such would be nice.

If they do implement a game rule like this, I think increased values should actually represent longer amounts of time (the opposite of how random tick speed works) so that it is very customizable.

Zero could mean theres no rusting at all, even if thats not really intuitive with the larger numbers = longer time system. Or maybe zero could be instant rusting and -1 could be no rusting.
I think a survival way to prevent rust would be even better
what about adding glass panes to the blocks to make them rust proof and shiny? (invisible glass, just no rust)
I want a gamerule that allows the specific time to be set.
*ahem* they've added "waxed" copper block variants that stop oxidization in its tracks anywhere along the progression line, be it at the start or finish. This happened a while back.
